ranked_diseases.explanation: Perfect match with all major features: highly elevated CK, calf pseudohypertrophy, Gowers sign, proximal>distal weakness pattern, respiratory insufficiency, and typical age of onset in a male patient.
Similar dystrophinopathy with elevated CK and muscle weakness, but typically milder and later onset. The severe presentation at age 5 with respiratory insufficiency favors DMD.
Gamma-sarcoglycanopathy can present similarly with proximal weakness, elevated CK, and calf hypertrophy, but Gowers sign and respiratory involvement at this age are less typical.
Alpha-sarcoglycanopathy presents with similar features but usually has later onset and less prominent calf pseudohypertrophy than seen in this patient.
MDC1A (merosin-deficient) can cause early weakness and hyperlordosis, but typically presents from birth with more severe motor delays and white matter changes on MRI.
SMA3 can present with proximal weakness and motor delays, but typically has normal or low CK levels and lacks calf pseudohypertrophy.
